method.name: GetDevices
method.tp:docstring: Get the list of network devices.

arg.name: devices
arg.tp:docstring: List of object paths of network devices known to the system.

method.name: GetDeviceByIpIface
method.tp:docstring: Return the object path of the network device referenced by its IP interface name. Note that some devices (usually modems) only have an IP interface name when they are connected.

arg.name: iface
arg.tp:docstring: Interface name of the device to find.

arg.name: device
arg.tp:docstring: Object path of the network device.

method.name: ActivateConnection
method.tp:docstring: Activate a connection using the supplied device.

arg.name: connection
arg.tp:docstring: The connection to activate. If "/" is given, a valid device path must be given, and NetworkManager picks the best connection to activate for the given device. VPN connections must always pass a valid connection path.

arg.name: device
arg.tp:docstring: The object path of device to be activated for physical connections. This parameter is ignored for VPN connections, because the specific_object (if provided) specifies the device to use.

arg.name: specific_object
arg.tp:docstring: The path of a connection-type-specific object this activation should use. This parameter is currently ignored for wired and mobile broadband connections, and the value of "/" should be used (ie, no specific object). For WiFi connections, pass the object path of a specific AP from the card's scan list, or "/" to pick an AP automatically. For VPN connections, pass the object path of an ActiveConnection object that should serve as the "base" connection (to which the VPN connections lifetime will be tied), or pass "/" and NM will automatically use the current default device.

arg.name: active_connection
arg.tp:docstring: The path of the active connection object representing this active connection.

method.name: AddAndActivateConnection
method.tp:docstring: Adds a new connection using the given details (if any) as a template (automatically filling in missing settings with the capabilities of the given device and specific object), then activate the new connection. Cannot be used for VPN connections at this time.

arg.name: connection
arg.tp:docstring: Connection settings and properties; if incomplete missing settings will be automatically completed using the given device and specific object.

arg.name: device
arg.tp:docstring: The object path of device to be activated using the given connection.

arg.name: specific_object
arg.tp:docstring: The path of a connection-type-specific object this activation should use. This parameter is currently ignored for wired and mobile broadband connections, and the value of "/" should be used (ie, no specific object). For WiFi connections, pass the object path of a specific AP from the card's scan list, which will be used to complete the details of the newly added connection.

arg.name: path
arg.tp:docstring: Object path of the new connection that was just added.

arg.name: active_connection
arg.tp:docstring: The path of the active connection object representing this active connection.

arg.name: active_connection
arg.tp:docstring: The currently active connection to deactivate.

method.name: Sleep
method.tp:docstring: Control the NetworkManager daemon's sleep state. When asleep, all interfaces that it manages are deactivated. When awake, devices are available to be activated. This command should not be called directly by users or clients; it is intended for system suspend/resume tracking.

arg.name: sleep
arg.tp:docstring: Indicates whether the NetworkManager daemon should sleep or wake.

method.name: Enable
method.tp:docstring: Control whether overall networking is enabled or disabled. When disabled, all interfaces that NM manages are deactivated. When enabled, all managed interfaces are re-enabled and available to be activated. This command should be used by clients that provide to users the ability to enable/disable all networking.

arg.name: enable
arg.tp:docstring: If FALSE, indicates that all networking should be disabled. If TRUE, indicates that NetworkManager should begin managing network devices.

method.name: GetPermissions
method.tp:docstring: Returns the permissions a caller has for various authenticated operations that NetworkManager provides, like Enable/Disable networking, changing WiFi, WWAN, and WiMAX state, etc.

arg.name: permissions
arg.tp:docstring: Dictionary of available permissions and results. Each permission is represented by a name (ie "org.freedesktop.NetworkManager.Foobar") and each result is one of the following values: "yes" (the permission is available), "auth" (the permission is available after a successful authentication), or "no" (the permission is denied). Clients may use these values in the UI to indicate the ability to perform certain operations.

signal.name: CheckPermissions
signal.tp:docstring: Emitted when system authorization details change, indicating that clients may wish to recheck permissions with GetPermissions.

method.name: SetLogging
method.tp:docstring: Set logging verbosity and which operations are logged.

arg.name: level
arg.tp:docstring: One of [ERR, WARN, INFO, DEBUG, TRACE].

arg.name: domains
arg.tp:docstring: A combination of logging domains separated by commas (','), or "NONE" to disable logging. Each domain enables logging for operations related to that domain. Available domains are: [PLATFORM, RFKILL, ETHER, WIFI, BT, MB, DHCP4, DHCP6, PPP, WIFI_SCAN, IP4, IP6, AUTOIP4, DNS, VPN, SHARING, SUPPLICANT, AGENTS, SETTINGS, SUSPEND, CORE, DEVICE, OLPC, WIMAX, INFINIBAND, FIREWALL, ADSL, BOND, VLAN, BRIDGE, DBUS_PROPS, TEAM, CONCHECK, DCB, DISPATCH, AUDIT]. In addition to these domains, the following special domains can be used: [NONE, ALL, DEFAULT, DHCP, IP]. You can also specify that some domains should log at a different level from the default by appending a colon (':') and a log level (eg, 'WIFI:DEBUG'). If an empty string is given, the log level is changed but the current set of log domains remains unchanged.

method.name: GetLogging
method.tp:docstring: Get current logging verbosity level and operations domains.

arg.name: level
arg.tp:docstring: One of [ERR, WARN, INFO, DEBUG, TRACE].

arg.name: domains
arg.tp:docstring: For available domains see SetLogging() call.

arg.name: connectivity
arg.tp:docstring: The current connectivity state.

method.name: state
method.tp:docstring: The overall networking state as determined by the NetworkManager daemon, based on the state of network devices under it's management.

property.name: Devices
property.tp:docstring: The list of network devices/interfaces NetworkManager knows about.

property.name: NetworkingEnabled
property.tp:docstring: Indicates if overall networking is currently enabled or not. See the Enable() method.

property.name: WirelessEnabled
property.tp:docstring: Indicates if wireless is currently enabled or not.

property.name: WirelessHardwareEnabled
property.tp:docstring: Indicates if the wireless hardware is currently enabled, i.e. the state of the RF kill switch.

property.name: WwanEnabled
property.tp:docstring: Indicates if mobile broadband devices are currently enabled or not.

property.name: WwanHardwareEnabled
property.tp:docstring: Indicates if the mobile broadband hardware is currently enabled, i.e. the state of the RF kill switch.

property.name: WimaxEnabled
property.tp:docstring: Indicates if WiMAX devices are currently enabled or not.

property.name: WimaxHardwareEnabled
property.tp:docstring: Indicates if the WiMAX hardware is currently enabled, i.e. the state of the RF kill switch.

property.name: ActiveConnections
property.tp:docstring: List of active connection object paths.

property.name: PrimaryConnection
property.tp:docstring: The object path of the "primary" active connection being used to access the network. In particular, if there is no VPN active, or the VPN does not have the default route, then this indicates the connection that has the default route. If there is a VPN active with the default route, then this indicates the connection that contains the route to the VPN endpoint.

property.name: PrimaryConnectionType
property.tp:docstring: The connection type of the "primary" active connection being used to access the network. This is the same as the Type property on the object indicated by PrimaryConnection.

property.name: Metered
property.tp:docstring: Indicates whether the connectivity is metered. This is equivalent to the metered property of the device associated with the primary connection.

property.name: ActivatingConnection
property.tp:docstring: The object path of an active connection that is currently being activated and which is expected to become the new PrimaryConnection when it finishes activating.

property.name: Startup
property.tp:docstring: Indicates whether NM is still starting up; this becomes FALSE when NM has finished attempting to activate every connection that it might be able to activate at startup.

property.name: State
property.tp:docstring: The overall state of the NetworkManager daemon.

arg.name: state
arg.tp:docstring: The new state of NetworkManager.

property.name: GlobalDnsConfiguration
property.tp:docstring: Dictionary of global DNS settings where the key is one of "searches", "options" and "domains". The values for the "searches" and "options" keys are string arrays describing the list of search domains and resolver options, respectively. The value of the "domains" key is a second-level dictionary, where each key is a domain name, and each key's value is a third-level dictionary with the keys "servers" and "options". "servers" is a string array of DNS servers, "options" is a string array of domain-specific options.

arg.name: properties
arg.tp:docstring: The changed properties.

signal.name: DeviceAdded
signal.tp:docstring: A device was added to the system

arg.name: device_path
arg.tp:docstring: The object path of the newly added device.

signal.name: DeviceRemoved
signal.tp:docstring: A device was removed from the system, and is no longer available.

arg.name: device_path
arg.tp:docstring: The object path of the device that was just removed.

tp:enum.name: NM_STATE
tp:enum.tp:docstring: Describes the overall state of the daemon.

tp:enumvalue.tp:docstring: Networking is inactive and all devices are disabled.
There is no active network connection.
Network connections are being cleaned up.
A network device is connecting to a network and there is no other available network connection.
A network device is connected, but there is only link-local connectivity.
A network device is connected, but there is only site-local connectivity.
A network device is connected, with global network connectivity.
The host is not connected to any network.
The host is behind a captive portal and cannot reach the full Internet.
The host is connected to a network, but does not appear to be able to reach the full Internet.
The host is connected to a network, and appears to be able to reach the full Internet
